name: Best of 2019
abstract: My personal round-up of the gaming year
words: here’s my highly personal round-up of the year. i didn’t get around to playing anywhere near as many games as i would’ve like (sorry,
, maybe 2020…) but, from what i did, these are my own individual highlights, arranged in the following categories:
best game that i actually managed to review in 2019
full reviews of 12 nintendo switch games
this year, and i thoroughly enjoyed the vast majority. however, some stood out head-and-shoulders about the rest:
is one of the highest regarded indie games on the switch, and for good reason: a thought-provoking storyline, tight platforming action, and a very well-designed overall package. it can be
frustrating at times, but the difficulty level is perfectly pitched to ensure you’ll progress
you give up. in fact, that’s sort of the underlying message:
blends its story and its gameplay into a single, unforgettable experience.
— a unique puzzler which reinvents its own challenges time and time again. if there’s any game from 2019 i’ll still be playing at the end of next year, without having finished, it’ll be this one.

a golf game combined with an rpg work? well, it does. the golfing action is about as perfect as it can be, without being over complicated, and the elements of humour in the game are — for the most part — well pitched.

some games are hyped, others appear seemingly out of nowhere. as i tend to play indie games, they typically fall into the latter category, but the entries in this category had the best hype/reward ratio.

helped launch the game boy and introduced portable, ‘casual’ gaming to tens of millions of people around the world. only a company like nintendo could repeat that trick, this time for its established hybrid platform, in a new-yet-familiar package. this was one of the events of the switch year, and although it might seem like a no-brainer in hindsight, i’m pretty sure nobody saw this one coming. a massively multiplayer version reinvented the classic and proved, once more, that nintendo knows
better than any of its competitors.
— a charming retro take on the metroidvania genre. from the 2-color graphics to the adorable animation, cleverly-crafted map, and increasingly challenging boss fights,
invoked strong feelings of gameboy-era platformers, with enough polish to be relevant in today’s gaming world.
only really played 3 tables in this collection of 19, not because the others aren’t any good (i wouldn’t know!), but because those 3 are so much fun.
there’s so much content in the demo of this breakout-like that i feel a bit guilty for not having bought the full thing! maybe that’s the idea — maybe that’s how
demos should be, but maybe that’s also what puts some publishers off putting out demos in the first place. anyway, take advantage: download for free and enjoy hours of free arcard action!
— a short demo of this gorgeous rpg due to release in 2020
— although it was first released in 2015, i only discovered this short survival game in 2019. inventive mechanics and a challenging task result in hours of gameplay — for whatever price you want.
outside of developers and publishers, i can’t think of anyone doing quite as much for indie gaming in 2019 as ‘the chick’. cathy vice reviews, promotes,
tweets, and inspires others to do the same. her reviews are a winning combination of experienced insight and profanity.
— a highly prolific reviewer with a winningly positive twitter feed

on the evidence of her twitter feed, loren is one of the most interesting and prolific developers around. weird organic patterns, cga-style colours, broken mathematical experiments, and the occasional caterpillar. loren’s feed is educational, inspirational, and never boring.

— in case the name wasn’t a giveaway, this dev from lithuania creates games about pigs. lots of games. about pigs. if you want insights about indie game development across the board, this is a great place to start.

— i knew ‘limmy’ as a comedian before discovering his stream this year; he has the driest sense of humour out of any streamer you’ll find!

although the switch is by far my primary gaming platform, i do also play games on the mac from time-to-time. it's not known as a strong gaming platform, but most of the standout indie games, and many higher profile ones, are available. i’ve got a shamefully high-quality backlog of steam games to deal with at some point, but for now, i only really got round to playing one new game on mac this year …

is still an inventive, addictive, hugely 
    fun piece of work. hits the sweet-spot of platformer, puzzler, and exploration. it’s also possibly the best example of pixelart in a popular game.

many of the games i played this year were released pre-2019 — after all, the best games tend to have a shelf-life longer than a single year, anyway. but i also managed to get my hands on a small number of new games in 2019, and these were the very best.

this was probably my most anticipated game of 2019 — heck, one of my most anticipated
    games of all time. for those of us who ‘missed out’ (chose to miss out?) on the
    wii u, the biggest regret was probably not being able to play super mario maker. 
    well,
super mario maker 2, in case you’re unaware, is 5 mario styles in one, from the much-loved nes original all the way through to the less-adored, but visually and mechanically evolved,
it’s 100 nintendo-created levels, just about as good as in any other mario platformer outside of
. it’s a near-unlimited supply of levels created by fans around the world — and some of these fans are devs known for other games including
choose to create, limited only by your imagination and the palette of classic mario elements available, from bullet bills to on/off switches and, finally, the much requested sloping ground.
era, it might have felt like the series was slowly coming to an end, somewhat tired and repetitive after decades of unsurpassed success.
totally revitalises things and is, surely, the ultimate mario experience, probably
high-point of the most significant video game in history.
both these games have already been mentioned, so it should be no surprise to see them here — simply, in my opinion, the best indie, and the second most playable game released this year.

— although the original will be at least 3 years old by the time this sequel hits (hopefully next year!), it’s still the best game released on the switch, by far. second time round, it’s unlikely to have
the same impact, but there are still millions of us waiting to spend another 100+ hours in the land of hyrule.
